answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hello, 
Although I was unable to find a direct answer to your question, I have located some documents that I hope will be helpful. 
This is a request for proposal from Habersham County, Georgia seeking an integrated system of departments to prevent duplication of services such as accounts payable, accounts receivable, general ledger, payroll, human resources, purchasing, fixed assets, project management, and cash collections.  While this is not quite an answer, it may be worth getting in contact with this local government to see what types of proposals were submitted: 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302077/RFP_Local_Government_Software_and_Implementation_Services 
I was also able to locate an “Accounts Receivable Toolkit” compiled by the California Department of Finance. This document gives best practices for collections on pages 6-7 of the pdf and “write-off” policies on pages 17-18 of the pdf: 
http://bit.ly/fbYKym 
Do any other members know of documents/best practices that may be relevant to this question? 
I hope this will at least begin to help answer your question! 
Amanda Dodge 
International City/County Management Association 
Knowledge Network Intern 
202-962-3699 
adodge@icma.org

author: Marshall Lewis
text:
Chesterfield County, Virginia is reviewing the many Accounts Receivable policies used by departments within our organization in order to create a new County-wide policy. Our goal is to improve consistency in collections practices for our customers, as well as ourselves, and increase funds collected. We are not looking for responses related to taxes. We appreciate you taking the time to answer the following questions about receivables and collections in your organization. Thank You!

Are your collection efforts centralized? 
If so, who is responsible for collection?
Do you use a third party collection vendor? 
If so, what vendor do you use? At what point do you turn receivables over to the third party? Who pays the third party fee?
Do you handle collections differently based on the amount you are owed?
If so, what thresholds do you use?
Do you have any collection techniques/tips that have increased the amount of money collected or made payment more timely?
Do you have Accounts Receivable policies? 
If so, can you share them? 
Do you litigate? 
If so, for what types of receivables?
How do you determine your write-offs?
May we contact you for additional information? If so, please provide your contact information.

Courtney Farrell
Accounting Department
Chesterfield, VA 23832
(804) 748-1233 phone
farrellc@chesterfield.gov
title: Accounts Receivable and Debt Collection Practices
